output.name: Advanced Scientific Programming in Python, Asia-Pacific summer school

githubOrganizationMetadata.name: Advanced Scientific Programming in Python, Asia-Pacific summer school

output.organizationTypeJustification: The organization is a community-led summer school for scientific Python, managed by the SciPy community (scipy-school.org), focused on open source educational workshops rather than a formal academic or corporate entity.
output.description: The Asia-Pacific regional summer school organized by the SciPy community, focusing on advanced scientific programming in Python. It offers hands-on workshops on advanced Python features, testing, documentation, parallel computing, numerical computing (NumPy, Cython, Numba), profiling, data tidying, visualization, software development (Git, debugging), and community tools.
relatedToOrganization: Asia-Pacific Society for Computers in Education

relatedToOrganization.legalName: Asia-Pacific Society for Computers in Education

disciplineJustification: Workshops on advanced Python programming, parallel Python, Cython and Numba, profiling and debugging demonstrate topics in Computer engineering
Data tidying and visualization workshops indicate a focus on handling and presenting information, aligned with Information engineering
The overall mission—applying Python to scientific problems across domains—places the organization within Applied sciences
output.relatedToEPFLJustification:
After systematically reviewing the organization metadata and all related sources, no evidence of an EPFL affiliation was found:
1. Organization name does not contain “EPFL” or any variant.
2. GitHub description is empty and does not mention EPFL/SDSC.
3. Website domain (scipy-school.org) is not an epfl.ch domain.
4. No parentOrganization or ROR entry linking to EPFL.
5. No README content or blog posts mentioning EPFL.
6. No location information indicating Lausanne, Switzerland.
7. No Infoscience entities associated with EPFL.
8. No membership in any EPFL GitHub organizations.
Given the absence of all positive signals, the cumulative confidence is 0.0, well below the 0.5 threshold.
